abstract.para: Even though the configuration of setroubleshoot does not require adjustment, you may face particular use cases, when you need to change the deafults. The following sections provide usual use cases.

topic.para: The configuration file for setroubleshoot is /etc/setroubleshoot. Usually, you do not have to modify the configuration besides setting the e-mail notifications. However, if you need to change the configuration, you can either open and edit the file, or you can use the setroubleshootd command to configure a particular item. section.title: Configuraing setroubleshoot logging level
section.para: The default logging level (the value of sealert_log and setroubleshootd_log) is set to warning. However, you can set the value to one of the following:

listitem.para: Only serious errors that prevent system from functioning are logged.
Serious errors that may influence the system are reported.
An indication that something unexpected happened, or that a problem might occur in the near future. However, the systems works as expected.
A confirmation that the system is running correctly is logged.
Detailed information for debugging purposes are logged.

section.title: Configuring setroubleshoot to send e-mail notifications
section.para: setroubleshoot can send you e-mail notifications if there is an AVC denial in the system.

step.para: Create the mail recipients file on the path definied by the recipeints_filepath option (/var/lib/setroubleshoot/email_alerts-recipients by default).
Each e-mail address must be on a separate line. Comments are denoted with the # symbol.

section.title: Configuring the setroubleshoot database
section.para: You can change the amount of records in the setroubleshootd database, its location of the file name prefix.

listitem.para: Specify an absolute path to the directory where the database XML file should reside.
Configure a custom prefix of the database file name. The file name then looks as follows: FILENAME_PREFIX_database.xml.
Defines the maximum number of records in the database. Specify 0 for an unlimited number of records.

Alerts older than the set limit are deleted from the database. You can use the units: year, month, day, hour, minte and second even in plural form and you can use more than one unit, for example, 3 weeks 2 days, which equals to 23 days. If left empty, there is no limit.
